Award.AwardTitle: Biochemical and Molecular Engineering XXI Conference

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 21st International Conference on Biochemical and Molecular Engineering (BME XXI) will be held in Mont Tremblant, Quebec. July 14-18, 2019. The theme of the BME XXI conference is Emerging Technologies in Tomorrow's Products and Processes, and it will be organized under the auspices of the Engineering Conferences International (ECI). This international conference will bring together established researchers, young investigators, private sector scientists and engineers as well as graduate students to assess the present and chart the future of the field of biochemical and molecular engineering.


The focus of the conference will be on microbial consortia (microbiome), systems metabolic engineering (systems biology to synthetic evolution), and emerging technologies (optogenetics and epigenetics) in combination with (protein engineering, process development, and scale up. One of the workshops, on Entrepreneurship, will highlight case studies from entrepreneurs around ideas/concepts that drive successful startups and business solutions. Another workshop, on Biochemical Engineering Education, will address important issues relating the industries need for a workforce trained in certain engineering areas, and academia's ever increasing focus on techniques to analyze Big Data/Modeling. The outcome of the meeting will be summarized by a report that will highlight opportunities and new directions in the area of biochemical and molecular engineering.

This award is being co-funded by CBET (CBE program) and MCB (CDF and SSB programs).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The chairs of the conference Rashmi Kshirsagar (Biogen), Steffen Schaffer (Evonik), Mattheos Koffas (RPI), and Christina Chan (Michigan State University) organized and brought together academic, industrial, and national laboratory researchers from 13 countries to the ECI BME meeting held in Fairmont Tremblant Mont Tremblant, Quebec, Canada on July 14-18, 2019. The conference included season as well as young faculty members, post-docs, and graduate students.

The conference contributed to the enhancement and improvement of scientific, engineering and/or educational activities by bringing together leaders from academia and industry along with young people in emerging fields of biochemical and molecular engineering. This meeting provided a foundation for collaborations between researchers. A diverse set of conference organizers worked together to ensure a broad and diverse set of attendees to benefit from the conference.

The conference provided a formal vehicle to highlight current and emerging research topics. Through plenary presentations, oral and poster sessions, workshops, and a panel discussion, BME XXI captured a number of emerging and established subjects and enabled high-level discussion and participation. The meeting held technical sessions covering recent advances such as optogenetic and epigenetic control of cell function. Specific workshops addressed needs in education and training. There were two workshops held, one workshop focused on modeling and analysis of big data and provided training and information on tools and techniques (specifically on Big Data/Modeling) relevant to conducting research in several emerging technology areas that would be useful to graduate students, post-docs, and faculty members. The second workshop highlighted case studies from academic entrepreneurs around ideas/concepts that drive successful startups and business solution which provided helpful information to academics interested in entrepreneurship and start-ups and also spur interest from industrial partners in planning a potential one next time that includes an industrial perspective. Abstracts for the two workshops are on the ECI website. In addition, presentations slides from the Big Data/Modeling workshop are on the ECI website. To maximize the value of this conference to academics, the conference also held a panel discussion that stimulated cross-fertilization of research advances presented in the sessions, which laid the groundwork for a BNB article that captured emerging research ideas and is published online.

The conference presentations, workshops, and panel discussion were captured in a report by Lara Marks that will be made available to the broader research community and the NSF. In addition the conference resulted in a BNB article led by Tim Whitehead that assilimated the panel discussion and highlighted emerging research topics and pointed to possible future conference topics and potential areas for future funding. A copy of Lara Marks report will be on the ECI website and the BNB article is published online.
